Imagine that at your birth, your brain is like a dense jungle. Moving through this jungle is difficult. When you have a thought for the first time, it‚Äôs like opening a new trail in the jungle. The more you think that thought, the easier it becomes to follow this trail, and the more you use this trail, the more you think that thought. Gradually, this trail becomes a path, then a road, and eventually an expressway.

Changing your belief system is like carving a new path in the jungle. Your brain, for energy efficiency, prefers to use the neural highway it has patiently created. So, it takes a conscious effort to create this new path.

If you know the destination of an old highway that no longer suits you (a limiting belief you have identified), it‚Äôs time to steer away from that highway by taking the new path you‚Äôve chosen (positive affirmation) again and again. This path will eventually become, too, a beautiful expressway, while the old one, no longer used, will be overtaken by vegetation, allowing for the emergence of a new sense of identity and a renewed self-perception.

Listen to your affirmations for 21 days, as often as possible, at least once a day. Repeat them out loud during the moments of silence, with the conviction that they are already true. Feel with gratitude that you are already becoming the person you wish to be.

To anchor them more deeply in your nervous system, engage your body: move, tense your muscles, put energy into your voice. These are not mere affirmations; they are powerful declarations. Feel what they awaken in you: sensations, emotions, images. Little by little, this practice transforms your thoughts, your actions, and thus your experience.

Your brain doesn‚Äôt distinguish between the imaginary and the real. Imagine your favorite dish‚Äîyou‚Äôre already salivating. Imagine a joyful scene‚Äîyou feel joy. Visualization is a concrete tool to transform your inner state.

To go further, visualize yourself truly living your affirmations. Activate your five senses: what do you see? what do you hear? what do you feel in your body? The more precise the image, the stronger the impact.
